choices.text: Adenylyl cyclase
Guanylyl cyclase
Phospholipase C

questions.text: Beta 2 receptor action leading to hyperglycemia/ hypoglycemia is mediated by which of the following enzymes? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Adenylyl cyclase

 

Explanation

 

Beta 2 receptor action leading to hypoglycemia/ hyperglycemia is mediated by adenylyl cyclase.

 

Catecholamines act through beta 2 receptors and they use adenylyl cyclase - CAMP second messenger system to stimulate the target tissues.

 

Cyclic AMP is synthesized from ATP by the action of the enzyme adenylyl cyclase.

 

  • Binding of the hormone to its receptor activates a G protein which, in turn, activates adenylyl cyclase
  • The resulting rise in cAMP turns on the appropriate response in the cell by either (or both):
    • Changing the molecular activities in the cytosol, often using Protein Kinase A (PKA) — a cAMP-dependent protein kinase that phosphorylates target proteins
    • Turning on a new pattern of gene transcription

 

Cyclic AMP produces one or more of the following responses:

 

  1. Contraction and relaxation of muscle fibers
  2. Alteration in the permeability of cell membrane
  3. Synthesis of substances inside the cell
  4. Secretion or release of substances by target cell
  5. Other physiological activities of the target cell

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Guanylyl cyclase: Incorrect. While guanylyl cyclase also produces a cyclic nucleotide (cGMP) that acts as a second messenger, it is not involved in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor pathway.

 

Option C. Phospholipase C: Incorrect. Phospholipase C is activated by Gq-coupled receptors, not Gs-coupled receptors like the beta-2 receptors. It catalyzes the breakdown of phosphatidylinositol bisphosphate into diacylglycerol and inositol triphosphate, which are involved in calcium signaling.

 

Option D. Phospholipase A2: Incorrect. This enzyme liberates arachidonic acid from phospholipids, leading to the production of eicosanoids (like prostaglandins and leukotrienes). It is not directly involved in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor signaling pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other hormones that use adenylyl cyclase - CAMP second messenger system are:

 

  • ACTH
  • Angiotensin II
  • Corticotropin-releasing hormone
  • Calcitonin
  • FSH
  • Glucagon
  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone
  • HCG
  • Luteinizing hormone
  • Parathyroid hormone
  • Secretin
  • Somatostatin
  • TSH
  • Vasopressin

choices.text: Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.
Apoferritin is the storage form.
Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood.
Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption.

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect about iron transport? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.

 

Iron metabolism involves complex processes where iron must be in the correct oxidation state to be absorbed and utilized effectively by the body. Iron in the diet is primarily found in the ferric (Fe3+) form, but for it to be absorbed across the apical membrane of enterocytes in the intestine, it needs to be converted into the ferrous (Fe2+) form. This conversion is crucial because only ferrous iron can be effectively transported into the cells. The statement in option A is incorrect because it suggests the opposite process—conversion from ferrous to ferric—before absorption, which is not accurate. The conversion actually goes from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) before iron is absorbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Apoferritin is the storage form: This statement is correct. Apoferritin binds with iron to form ferritin, which is the storage form of iron within cells.

 

Option C. Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood: This is also correct. After iron is absorbed into the bloodstream, it binds to the protein transferrin, which transports it to various tissues, including the bone marrow for hemoglobin production.

 

Option D. Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption: This statement is true. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) reduces ferric iron (Fe3+) to ferrous iron (Fe2+), which enhances its absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron must be converted from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) form for effective absorption through the apical membrane of enterocytes

questions.text: A 32-year-old farmer was brought to the emergency after he suddenly became unconscious while working in the field. On examination, his temperature was 105 degrees Fahrenheit and his skin turgor was decreased. Which of the following would not be seen in the patient?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sweating

 

Explanation

 

In the scenario described, the patient likely suffers from heatstroke, characterized by a high body temperature (105°F), altered consciousness, and dehydration (indicated by decreased skin turgor).

 

Heatstroke is a severe form of heat illness that occurs when the body's heat-dissipating mechanisms fail. One of the classic signs, especially in exertional heatstroke, is the cessation of sweating, despite the elevated body temperature. This lack of sweating is due to dehydration and the body's inability to maintain adequate heat loss through evaporation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Tachypnea - Rapid, deep breathing (Kussmaul breathing) can be seen in heatstroke

 

Option B: Hypotension - Dehydration and vasodilation in an attempt to dissipate heat can result in hypotension in heatstroke.

 

Option D: Red hot skin - Heatstroke patients can present with hot, flushed skin due to increased blood flow to the skin surface and the body's inability to dissipate heat effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Difference between Fever and Heatstroke is as follows:

choices.text: Blunt object with high force doesn’t stimulate nociceptors
Pinching with serrated object stimulate mechanoceptors but doesn’t cause pain
Sharp pain sensation is carried by type C nerve fiber

questions.text: Mechanical nociceptors and its response to a probe with blunt object, pin prick and tooth forceps with serration is recorded as a output of a force transducer coupled to the stimulator. What will you infer from a given diagram? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blunt object with high force doesn't stimulate nociceptors

 

Blunt Object:

 

  • Does not produce action potentials in nociceptors
  • Activates mechanoreceptors without triggering pain sensation
  • High force does not necessarily stimulate nociceptive receptors

 

Pin Prick:

 

  • Produces clear action potentials
  • Stimulates nociceptors
  • Sharp stimuli trigger pain receptors

 

Serrated Forceps:

 

  • Produces multiple action potentials
  • Stimulates both mechanoreceptors and nociceptors
  • Causes significant pain response

 

Sharp pain is typically carried by A-delta fibers

 

Slower, diffuse pain is carried by C fibers

 

Nociceptors respond to potentially tissue-damaging stimuli

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nociceptors (pain receptors) respond differentially to various mechanical stimuli - they are activated by sharp objects and pinching/pressure that can potentially damage tissue, but not by blunt pressure even with high force. Fast, sharp pain is transmitted via A-delta fibers, while slow, dull pain is transmitted via C fibers.

questions.text: Which receptor helps in improvement of insulin resistance in Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus with regular exercise and physical activity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GLUT4

 

GLUT4 is a glucose transporter found primarily in adipose tissues and striated muscles (skeletal and cardiac). It is insulin-dependent, meaning its activity increases in response to insulin. During exercise, the translocation of GLUT4 to the cell membrane is stimulated, enhancing glucose uptake into cells even in the absence of insulin. This mechanism is crucial in improving insulin sensitivity and combating insulin resistance, particularly in individuals with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM2). Regular physical activity enhances this effect, leading to better glucose control and reduction of hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GLUT1: This glucose transporter is found in many tissues, including the brain, and is responsible for basal glucose uptake. It is not significantly influenced by insulin and does not play a direct role in improving insulin resistance in DM2.

 

Option C. GLUT2: GLUT2 is primarily found in the liver, pancreas, kidneys, and intestines. It functions in glucose sensing and plays a role in glucose homeostasis but is not directly involved in the insulin-dependent improvement of glucose uptake seen in DM2.

 

Option D. GLUT3: GLUT3 is a high-affinity glucose transporter found predominantly in neurons. It ensures a constant supply of glucose to the brain, but it is not insulin-dependent and does not have a significant role in the management of insulin resistance in DM2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT4 is the insulin-dependent glucose transporter that plays a key role in improving insulin resistance with regular exercise and physical activity.

questions.text: How is cerebral perfusion pressure calculated? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mean arterial pressure - intracranial pressure


Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated as mean arterial pressure (MAP) - intracranial pressure (ICP).

 

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is the net pressure gradient that drives oxygen delivery to cerebral tissue. It is the difference between the mean arterial pressure (MAP) and the intracranial pressure (ICP), measured in millimeters of mercury (mm Hg). If ICP values are not readily available, central venous pressure (CVP) may be used.

 

Normal CPP lies between 60- and 80-mm Hg,

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated by subtracting the intracranial pressure (ICP) from the mean arterial pressure (MAP). This measurement is crucial for ensuring adequate blood flow and oxygen delivery to the brain.

questions.text: A person develops headache and breathlessness on a trekking expedition following rapid ascent to over 3000 metres above the sea level. Which of the following is not used in treatment of the above condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IV digoxin

 

The condition described in the scenario is likely High-Altitude Headache (HAH) and High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE), which can occur due to rapid ascent to high altitudes.

 

Digoxin is a medication primarily used for the treatment of heart conditions, such as heart failure and certain irregular heart rhythms like atrial fibrillation therefore, digoxin is not used for the above condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immediate Descent: This is the most effective treatment for HAPE and other altitude sickness symptoms. Descending to lower altitudes where the air pressure is higher can alleviate symptoms by increasing the available oxygen.

 

Option C. Administration of Oxygen: Providing supplemental oxygen can help alleviate the symptoms of hypoxia experienced at high altitudes, directly addressing the oxygen deficit caused by the thin air.

 

Option D. Tablet Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a diuretic that helps prevent and reduce the symptoms of altitude sickness. It works by acidifying the blood, which stimulates breathing, increasing oxygen intake and helping the body adjust to changes in altitude.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barometric pressure, partial pressure of oxygen and common effects at different altitudes

 

 

Treatment

 

  1. Oxygen supplementation
  2. Move to a lower altitude
  3. Acetazolamide – stimulates respiration and reduced intracranial pressure
  4. Portable hyperbaric bags (E.g., Gamow bag) simulate descent to a lower altitude.

choices.text: First becomes more positive, then negative

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He had severe muscle injury and his serum K+ level was found to be 5.5 mEq/L. What change will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Becomes more positive

 

Explanation

 

In the given clinical scenario, the patient has hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia can cause a shift in the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value, increased cell excitability, and impairments in membrane potential changes.

 

Hyperkalemia can affect the resting membrane potential of cells, including neurons and muscle cells, in the following ways:

 

  1. Increased Resting Membrane Potential: Normally, the resting membrane potential is around -70 millivolts (mV) in neurons. However, in hyperkalemia, the elevated extracellular potassium concentration can lead to an increased positive charge outside the cell. This positive charge tends to depolarize the cell membrane, shifting the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value.
  2. Altered Excitability: The increased resting membrane potential caused by hyperkalemia can make the cell more excitable. It reduces the threshold required for an action potential to be initiated, making the cell more likely to depolarize and generate an action potential even in response to weaker stimuli.
  3. Impaired Membrane Potential Changes: Hyperkalemia can interfere with the ability of the cell membrane to depolarize and repolarize properly during an action potential. It reduces the electrochemical gradient for sodium (Na+) entry during depolarization and decreases the driving force for potassium (K+) exit during repolarization. This can result in slower and less efficient propagation of action potentials.
  4.  Disrupted Ionic Balance: Elevated potassium levels can disrupt the balance of other ions, such as sodium and calcium, which are essential for normal cell function. The altered ionic balance can interfere with the proper functioning of ion channels and other membrane proteins involved in generating and regulating action potentials.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No change: Incorrect. Changes in extracellular potassium concentrations directly impact the resting membrane potential.

 

Option B. Becomes more negative: Incorrect. An increase in extracellular potassium concentration results in depolarization (more positive resting membrane potential), not hyperpolarization.

 

Option D. First becomes more positive, then negative: Incorrect. While complex fluctuations can occur under dynamic conditions, primarily, hyperkalemia causes a persistent depolarization (more positive shift) without an initial opposite change.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hyperkalemia, as seen in patients with severe muscle injury, the resting membrane potential becomes more positive due to decreased potassium efflux, leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells. This can affect the normal function of these cells, potentially leading to complications such as muscle weakness or cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: A patient is presenting with a staggering gait and nystagmus (Rhomberg sign +ve) after a road traffic accident. Which lobe of cerebellum is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flocculonodular

 

The symptoms described—staggering gait, nystagmus, and a positive Rhomberg sign—are indicative of damage to the cerebellum, specifically the flocculonodular lobe. The flocculonodular lobe is responsible for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex, which is crucial for stabilizing vision during head movements. The presence of nystagmus (involuntary eye movements) suggests a disturbance in the vestibulo-ocular reflex, pointing towards a lesion in the flocculonodular lobe. This part of the cerebellum is particularly involved in coordinating the balance and equilibrium of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dentate: The dentate nucleus is involved in the planning and execution of fine motor movements rather than the maintenance of balance and posture.

 

Option C. Anterior lobe: The anterior lobe of the cerebellum is primarily associated with coordinating limb movements and maintaining muscle tone.

 

Option D. Vermis: The vermis is responsible for controlling the body's midline movements, such as the trunk and head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum is crucial for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex. Damage to this area can lead to symptoms such as a staggering gait, nystagmus, and balance issues, as seen in the case of cerebellar ataxia following trauma.

questions.text: Insulin independent absorption occurs in all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adipose

 

Glucose uptake in adipose tissue is insulin-dependent, primarily using GLUT4 transporters activated by insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC: Red Blood Cells utilize GLUT1 transporters for glucose absorption, which is insulin-independent and crucial for their energy needs.

 

Option C. Pancreas: While the pancreas plays a role in insulin production, its glucose absorption is not predominantly insulin-independent.

 

Option D. Brain: The brain absorbs glucose independently of insulin, using GLUT3 transporters, essential for its constant energy requirements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose uptake in adipose tissue is insulin-dependent, while RBCs, pancreas, and brain utilize insulin-independent mechanisms for glucose absorption.

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.text: A patient met with a road traffic accident and developed a cervical spine injury. The fracture fragment had pierced the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract. Which of the following findings is seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception

 

Explanation

 

The above clinical scenario depicts transection of the spinal cord in the lateral aspect of the dorsal column would affect the fasciculus cuneatus. This lesion would result in absence of ipsilateral proprioception of the arm.

 

 

The fibers in the dorsal column are arranged in such a manner that the sacral segments are positioned most medially and those from the cervical segments are positioned most laterally.

 

These are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus gracilis - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb
  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus cuneatus - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral upper limb.

 

Fasciculus Gracilis and Cuneatus functions:

 

  1. Fine touch
  2. Tactile localization
  3. Tactile discrimination
  4. Vibration

 

This patient with an injury to the lateral part of the cervical cord's dorsal column tract will have damaged fasciculus cuneatus. This would result in loss of touch, vibration, and proprioception in the arm of the same side of the lesion.

 

function below the level of injury. The clue to solving this question is that the question mentions that the damage is to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception: This would be seen if the fasciculus gracilis was affected, which is responsible for carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb.

 

Option B. Absence of fine motor movement of fingers: This would be a result of damage to the corticospinal tract, which carries motor information.

 

Option D. Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception: Proprioception is carried by the dorsal column pathway, and it is affected ipsilaterally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract in the cervical spine region results in the loss of ipsilateral arm proprioception due to the involvement of the fasciculus cuneatus. This emphasizes the importance of the dorsal column in carrying proprioceptive and fine tactile information from the upper limbs.

 

Additional Information

 

Brown Sequard Syndrome (Hemi-sectioning of spinal cord)

 

  • I/L loss of Fine touch
  • C/L loss of Pain & Temperature
  • I/L loss of Proprioception
  • I/L motor paralysis

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased
Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.text: A preterm baby who was delivered at 28 weeks developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Surface tension - increased; Compliance - decreased

 

Explanation

 

This preterm baby who developed respiratory distress syndrome has surfactant deficiency. Due to which surface tension increases and compliance decreases.

 

Surfactant (Lecithin/Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl Choline) is produced by specialized cells called type II alveolar cells in the lungs. Surfactant molecules have a hydrophilic (water-attracting) head and a hydrophobic (water-repellent) tail. This unique structure allows surfactant to lower the surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveoli. It reduces the attractive forces between water molecules, preventing the alveoli from collapsing during expiration.

 

Compliance refers to the ability of the lungs to expand and recoil efficiently during breathing. Without surfactant, the surface tension within the alveoli would be high, making it difficult for the lungs to inflate during inspiration and causing them to collapse more readily during expiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preterm infants, especially those born before the lungs have matured at around 28 weeks, the lack of adequate surfactant leads to increased surface tension and decreased compliance, contributing to the development of respiratory distress syndrome.

choices.text: At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is refractory period

questions.text: True statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Point B to D is refractory period

 

Explanation:

 

The correct statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is point B to D is the refractory period.

 

 

AT POINT 1 - Resting membrane potential: membrane is more permeable to K+ than Na+ at rest. Voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels are closed.

 

AT POINT 2 - Membrane depolarization: Na+ activation gate opens à Na+ flows inward.

 

AT POINT 3 - Membrane repolarization: Na+ inactivation gate closes at peak potential, thus stopping Na+ inflow. K+ activation gate opens → K+ flows outward.

 

AT POINT 4 - Membrane hyperpolarization: K+ activation gates are slow to close → excess K+ efflux and brief period of hyperpolarization. Voltage-gated Na+ channels switch back to resting state. Na+/K+ pump restores ions concentration.

 

Point 2 to 4 is a part of the refractory period. During this period, the application of even a stronger stimulus will not elicit an action potential.

 

The refractory period is divided into two, an absolute refractory period and a relative refractory period. During the absolute refractory period, the nerve will not be excited no matter how strong a stimulus is given. However, during the relative refractory period, stronger than normal stimuli can cause excitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect. Threshold potential is reached just before point B where a rapid depolarization phase begins.

 

Option B: Incorrect. At point E, the nerve is not more excitable; rather, it is in a hyperpolarized state where more than the normal stimulus would be needed to generate another action potential.

 

Option C: Incorrect. The transition from C to D is characterized by the closing of Na+ channels and the opening of K+ channels, not the other way around.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phases of an action potential -

 

  • Point A: Represents the resting membrane potential.
  • Point B: Marks the threshold potential.

 

Point C: Represents the peak of the action potential.

 

  • Point D: Repolarization phase
  • Point E: Hyperpolarization phase
  • Absolute refractory period includes points B to around point C
  • Relative refractory period from around point C to D

questions.text: What is the value of normal Glomerular oncotic pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 32 mmHg

 

The value of normal Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure is 32 mmHg.

 

Oncotic pressure, or colloid osmotic-pressure, is a form of osmotic pressure induced by the proteins, notably albumin, in a blood vessel's plasma (blood/liquid. that causes a pull-on fluid back into the capillary. Participating colloids displace water molecules, thus creating a relative water molecule deficit with water molecules moving back into the circulatory system within the lower venous pressure end of capillaries.

 

It is mostly negligible, but sometimes can be as high as 6 mmHg in the brain. The values are also positive in the liver and kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal glomerular oncotic pressure is approximately 32 mmHg, which helps maintain fluid balance by drawing water back into the capillaries.

questions.text: The motor supply of the muscle spindle is which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gamma neuron

 

Gamma motor neurons specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers within the muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha (α) neuron: Alpha motor neurons innervate extrafusal muscle fibers, which are the main contractile units of the muscle, and are not involved in the direct control of muscle spindle sensitivity.

 

Option C. Beta (β) neuron: A Beta neurons are sensory in nature, so they neither supply extrafusal nor intrafusal muscle fibers.

 

Option D. Delta (δ) neuron: Delta neurons are sensory neurons that transmit pain, temperature, and coarse touch sensations. They do not provide motor supply to muscle spindles or any other muscle fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma motor neurons (A gamma) specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers of muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

questions.text: How would you describe the tonicity of the fluid leaving the proximal convoluted tubule in the absence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isotonic

 

Fluid leaving the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT in the absence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is isotonic.

 

Normally, about 65 per cent of the filtered load of sodium and water and a slightly lower percentage of filtered chloride are reabsorbed by the proximal tubule before the filtrate reaches the loops of Henle. The PCT is the site of maximum water reabsorption under normal physiological conditions. Isosmotic reabsorption occurs in the PCT, so the amount of solute and water reabsorbed are coupled and proportional to each other. Water reabsorption in the PCT also occurs through aquaporin-1 which are active water channels. Reabsorption of sodium and water in PCT is not affected by ADH levels.

 

Thus, even in the absence of ADH, fluid is isotonic in PCT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypotonic: This is incorrect because the fluid in the PCT remains isotonic due to the proportional reabsorption of solutes and water.

 

Option C. Hypertonic: This is incorrect because the reabsorption process in the PCT maintains the isotonic nature of the fluid.

 

Option D. Depends on fluid intake: This is incorrect because the tonicity of the fluid in the PCT does not depend on fluid intake but on the intrinsic reabsorption processes that maintain isotonic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluid leaving the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) is isotonic due to the isosmotic reabsorption of solutes and water, regardless of the presence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). This ensures that the fluid entering the loop of Henle has the same osmolarity as plasma.

choices.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers

 

Explanation

 

In the above scenario, the patient has developed paresis (partial paralysis) but the pain sensation is intact (no numbness) suggests A fibers involvement as they carry motor, touch, and pressure sensations are most sensitive to pressure changes/compression.

 

A fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for transmitting signals related to touch, pressure, and proprioception (the sense of one's body position). C fibers, on the other hand, are unmyelinated and transmit slower pain signals. While both types of fibers can be affected by pressure, A fibers are more vulnerable to damage from sustained pressure than C fibers, which are more resistant to compression.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers. - Incorrect. C fibers are unmyelinated and relatively more resistant to pressure compared to myelinated A fibers.

 

Option B. A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers. - Not relevant to the scenario, as the issue is related to mechanical pressure, not oxygen deprivation.

 

Option D. A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers. - Also not relevant to the given scenario, focusing on hypoxia instead of the impact of mechanical pressure or compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative susceptibility -

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presented with slowly progressive motor weakness, nuchal rigidity, and difficulty in swallowing and carrying out day-to-day activities. A provisional diagnosis of multiple sclerosis is suspected. Which of the following cells are affected in multiple sclerosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oligodendrocytes

 

Explanation

 

Oligodendrocytes are affected in multiple sclerosis.

 

In multiple sclerosis (MS), myelin-forming oligodendrocytes (OLGs) are the targets of inflammatory and immune attacks. OLG death by apoptosis or necrosis causes the cell loss seen in MS plaques, and leads to loss of conduction or delayed conduction in the demyelinated axons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microglia. are the primary immune cells of the central nervous system, similar to peripheral macrophages.

 

Option C. Astrocytes. also known collectively as astroglia, are characteristic star-shaped glial cells in the brain and spinal cord. They perform many functions, including biochemical control of endothelial cells that form the blood–brain barrier.

 

Option D. Ependymal cells. are ciliated-epithelial glial cells that develop from radial glia along the surface of the ventricles of the brain and the spinal canal. They play a critical role in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) homeostasis, brain metabolism, and the clearance of waste from the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In multiple sclerosis, the primary pathological change occurs in oligodendrocytes, the cells responsible for myelinating neurons in the CNS. This leads to widespread neurological impairment due to the loss of myelin, affecting the efficiency of nerve signal transmission.

choices.text: Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus
When 02 and CO2 ratio is equal
The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg

questions.text: V/Q = infinity holds true in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Equal to dead space

 

Explanation

 

VA/Q= infinity suggests that Q is 0 which implies that there is no exchange of 02 & CO2, and no gaseous exchange occurs in dead space.

 

In quantitative terms, the ventilation-perfusion ratio is expressed as Va/Q. When Va (alveolar ventilation) is normal for a given alveolus and Q (blood flow) is also normal for the same alveolus, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (Va/Q) is also said to be normal.

 

This ratio explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus: Incorrect, as this condition would lead to an area with no ventilation (blocked by the foreign body) potentially resulting in a low V/Q ratio in the affected area rather than an infinite V/Q ratio.

 

Option C. When O2 and CO2 ratio is equal: Incorrect, as this does not directly relate to the ventilation-perfusion ratio concept. This option is more a reflection of gas exchange effectiveness rather than a description of V/Q mismatches.

 

Option D. The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg: Incorrect, these values are typical for normal alveolar air and do not indicate a V/Q mismatch situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VA /Q ratio is infinite in the following scenarios -

 

  1. Ventilation is normal but there is no perfusion.
  2. No gaseous exchange through the respiratory membranes of corresponding alveoli.
  3. The alveolar air equilibrates the humidified inspired air.
  4. Partial pressures of the 02 and CO, are 149 mmHg & 0 mm Hg respectively.

choices.text: Intracellular fluid
Extracellular fluid

questions.text: A body fluid sample is being studied and has Na: 10 mEq/L, K: 140 mEq/L, CI: 4 mE/L. Identify the compartment from which the sample has been obtained? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intracellular fluid

 

Explanation

 

The electrolyte composition in the sample obtained has high concentration of potassium, suggests that it is intracellular fluid (IC) compartment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial and Option C. Extracellular Fluid generally have higher sodium and chloride concentrations and much lower potassium concentrations.

 

Option D. Plasma, part of the extracellular fluid, would similarly show higher sodium and chloride but lower potassium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The composition of potassium, sodium, and chloride in the sample aligns with that typically found in intracellular fluid, reflecting its origin from within cells, where potassium is the major cation, unlike extracellular compartments dominated by sodium and chloride.

choices.text: The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less
Decreased release of 02
It has less P50
It is less acidic

questions.text: What makes CPDA superior than ACD for blood storage? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less

 

Explanation

 

The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less when the blood is stored in CPDA compared with ACD.

 

The ease with which hemoglobin releases oxygen to the tissues is controlled by erythrocytic 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) such that an increase in the concentration of 2,3-DPG decreases oxygen affinity and vice versa.

 

In stored blood, the 2,3 DPG levels usually fall, thus less oxygen is released to the tissues. Therefore, its use in hypoxic patients (E.g., anemia) is limited.

 

Phosphate-containing solution like CPDA (Citrate, phosphate, dextrose, adenine) prevents the fall in 2.3DPG levels. Higher 2,3 DPG concentration decreases affinity of Hb to the oxygen releasing oxygen to the tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased release of O2: Incorrect. The goal of effective blood storage solutions like CPDA is to ensure that the oxygen release capacity is maintained, not decreased. CPDA helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG, which enhances the release of oxygen to tissues.

 

Option C. It has less P50: Incorrect. P50 is a measure of the oxygen tension at which hemoglobin is 50% saturated with oxygen. A higher P50, indicative of lower oxygen affinity, is preferable in stored blood as it means oxygen is more readily released to tissues—a trait supported by higher 2,3-DPG levels.

 

Option D. It is less acidic: Incorrect. While pH maintenance is important in blood storage, the primary benefit of CPDA over ACD is not related to less acidity but to its inclusion of phosphate and adenine, which help sustain energy (ATP) production and 2,3-DPG levels in red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of CPDA in blood storage is superior to ACD due to its phosphate content, which helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG in stored red blood cells. This biochemical preservation is crucial for ensuring that transfused blood can effectively release oxygen to hypoxic tissues, making CPDA the preferred choice in clinical settings where blood transfusions are necessary.

questions.text: Catecholamine secretion is increased by all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperglycemia

 

Catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine) are released from the adrenal medulla and sympathetic nerve terminals in response to various physiological stressors. Their secretion is typically increased during situations that trigger the "fight or flight" response.

 

Hyperglycemia does not stimulate catecholamine release because high blood glucose levels don't represent a threat to the body that requires mobilization of energy resources. Catecholamines work to increase blood glucose through glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. Once glucose levels are already elevated, there's no physiological need for additional catecholamine release.

 

Catecholamine release occurs during hypoglycemia, quiet standing, surgery, smoking, exercise, and is highest in conditions like pheochromocytoma, myocardial infarction, and ketoacidosis. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoglycemia: Incorrect. Hypoglycemia is a potent stimulus for catecholamine release. When blood glucose levels fall below normal, catecholamines are released to mobilize glucose stores and increase blood glucose through glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. This is an essential protective mechanism to ensure adequate glucose supply to the brain and other vital organs during periods of low blood glucose.

 

Option C. Smoking: Incorrect. Smoking causes nicotine to enter the bloodstream, which stimulates the adrenal medulla to release catecholamines. The nicotine in cigarettes acts on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the adrenal medulla and sympathetic ganglia, triggering the release of epinephrine and norepinephrine. This is part of the physiological response that leads to increased heart rate and blood pressure observed in smokers.

 

Option D. Exercise: Incorrect. Exercise is a significant stimulus for catecholamine release. During physical activity, there's an increased demand for energy and oxygen delivery to working muscles. The sympathetic nervous system is activated, leading to the release of epinephrine and norepinephrine. These catecholamines help in increasing heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate, and they mobilize energy sources to support the increased metabolic demands of exercise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Catecholamine secretion increases during stress conditions like hypoglycemia, smoking, and exercise, but not during hyperglycemia.

choices.text: Binding to beta subunit of Hb

questions.text: 2,3-BPG causes the unloading of oxygen to tissues by?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Binding to beta subunit of Hb

 

2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) causes the unloading of oxygen to tissues by binding to the beta subunit of hemoglobin (Hb). This binding decreases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, thereby facilitating the release of oxygen to the tissues.

 

  • 2,3-BPG Role: 2,3-BPG is a byproduct of glycolysis in red blood cells (RBCs) and plays a crucial role in regulating oxygen delivery. It binds to the deoxygenated form of hemoglobin, stabilizing it and promoting the release of oxygen.

 

  • Binding to Beta Subunit: 2,3-BPG binds specifically to the beta subunits of hemoglobin in the central cavity formed by the four subunits. This interaction stabilizes the T (tense) state of hemoglobin, which has a lower affinity for oxygen, thus promoting oxygen unloading.

 

  • Physiological Conditions: Conditions such as high altitude and exercise increase the levels of 2,3-BPG in RBCs, enhancing oxygen release to meet the increased metabolic demand of tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increasing ATP production: This is incorrect because 2,3-BPG does not directly increase ATP production. It is a byproduct of glycolysis but its primary role in this context is to modulate hemoglobin's oxygen affinity.

 

Option C. Inhibiting taut structure: This is incorrect because 2,3-BPG actually stabilizes the T (tense) state of hemoglobin, which is the low-affinity state.

 

Option D. Decreasing ATP production: This is incorrect as 2,3-BPG's function in oxygen unloading is not related to altering ATP production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) binds to the beta subunits of hemoglobin, decreasing its affinity for oxygen and promoting oxygen release to the tissues. This mechanism is crucial for adapting to conditions requiring increased oxygen delivery, such as high altitude and exercise.

choices.text: By increasing osteoclastic activity and decreasing renal excretion of calcium

questions.text: The adjoining graph shows the effect of PTH on blood calcium and phosphate in an experimental animal. How does PTH increase plasma calcium? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) By increasing osteoclastic activity and decreasing renal excretion of calcium

 

Explanation:

 

PTH increases calcium levels by promoting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption and reducing the kidneys' excretion of calcium, effectively increasing plasma calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. By increasing osteoclast activity: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) stimulates osteoclasts indirectly, leading to increased bone resorption, which releases calcium into the bloodstream.

 

Option B. By increasing osteoblastic activity: While PTH does stimulate osteoblasts, this action is primarily to produce RANKL, a cytokine that activates osteoclasts, not to build new bone.

 

Option C. By decreasing renal excretion: PTH reduces calcium excretion by the kidneys, increasing reabsorption of calcium in the renal tubules, contributing to higher blood calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases plasma calcium levels by promoting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption and reducing renal excretion of calcium.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions prolactin level is highest?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 24 hours after delivery

 

Explanation

 

Among the given options, the prolactin level is highest 24 hours after delivery.

 

This hormone is secreted by the mother’s anterior pituitary gland, and its concentration in her blood rises steadily from the fifth week of pregnancy until birth of the baby, at which time it has risen to 10 to 20 times the normal nonpregnant level.

 

  • 24 Hours After Delivery: Following childbirth, prolactin levels are significantly elevated to facilitate breastfeeding. These levels are particularly high immediately postpartum as the body prepares to produce milk to feed the newborn. This is the period when prolactin levels are typically at their highest among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24 hours after ovulation: Although hormonal changes related to the menstrual cycle do affect prolactin levels, these changes are moderate and do not typically reach the peak levels seen postpartum. The role of prolactin around ovulation is less pronounced compared to its surge after delivery, where it is critical for initiating and sustaining lactation.

 

Option C. NREM Sleep: Prolactin levels naturally rise during sleep, especially during the deeper stages of NREM sleep, due to reduced dopamine activity, which normally inhibits prolactin secretion. Despite this increase, the levels achieved during sleep are usually not as high as those observed after childbirth, where prolactin plays a direct and significant role in breastfeeding.

 

Option D. After running for 1 hour: Physical activities and stress can lead to an increase in prolactin levels as part of the body's response to physiological stress or exertion. However, these increases are generally transient and significantly lower than the sustained high levels required for lactation post-delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other factors which leads to high prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) in the body are:

 

During sleep, the hypothalamus releases dopamine, which inhibits the secretion of jectiveprolactin. As the night progresses and sleep deepens, dopamine levels decrease, leading to a decrease in the inhibition of prolactin release. Consequently, prolactin levels rise, reaching their peak in the early morning hours.

 

Prolactinoma: The most common cause of hyperprolactinemia is a noncancerous tumour of the pituitary gland called a prolactinoma.

 

Medications: Certain medications can increase prolactin levels. These include antipsychotic (such as risperidone and haloperidol), antidepressants, anti-nausea drugs (such as metoclopramide), and some high blood pressure medications.

 

Hypothyroidism: Underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) can disrupt the normal balance of hormones in the body, including prolactin regulation.

 

Chronic Kidney Disease: Kidney dysfunction or chronic kidney disease can lead to hyperprolactinemia. Impaired kidney function affects the clearance of prolactin from the blood, leading to elevated levels.

 

Stress and Emotional Factors: Extreme stress, emotional trauma, or intense physical activity can temporarily raise prolactin levels.

 

Pregnancy and Breastfeeding: During pregnancy, prolactin levels increase to prepare the breasts for milk production. After childbirth, prolactin levels remain elevated to stimulate and maintain breastfeeding.

questions.text: In the adjoining image of the muscle fiber action potential, the phase marked B is due to which of the following? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Efflux of potassium

 

The phase marked B in the muscle fiber action potential graph typically represents the repolarization phase of the action potential.

 

During repolarization, potassium channels open, allowing K+ to flow out of the cell, which returns the membrane potential back toward its resting value.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Influx of potassium: Influx of K+ occurs during the resting condition by Na+ K+ Pump, not during the repolarization phase of an action potential.

 

Option C. Sodium efflux: Sodium (Na+) influx, not efflux, is responsible for the depolarization phase (Not for the repolarization), where the membrane potential rapidly rises, preceding phase B.

 

Option D. Calcium influx: Calcium influx is more related to the initiation of muscle contraction following the depolarization phase, not directly related to the action potential of nerve or repolarization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The repolarization phase of a muscle fiber action potential is primarily due to the efflux of potassium ions (K+) from the cell, which restores the membrane potential to its resting state.

choices.text: Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to right sensory cortex
Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to left sensory cortex

questions.text: After a right limb amputation, the patient is experiencing severe pain (phantom limb). What is the mechanism behind this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to left sensory cortex

 

When a limb is amputated, the sensory input from that limb is lost. However, the brain's sensory cortex, which was originally responsible for receiving input from that limb, does not remain idle. Due to the phenomenon known as cortical plasticity, the brain adapts by allowing adjacent areas of the sensory cortex to project their fibers into the area that previously received input from the amputated limb.

 

Since sensory information from the right limb is processed in the contralateral (left) sensory cortex, it is the left sensory cortex that experiences changes. The adjacent fibers from neighboring cortical areas begin to overlap and take over the area previously occupied by the input from the now-amputated right limb. This can lead to the sensation of phantom pain, where the patient feels pain in the missing limb as the brain "misinterprets" signals from these newly connected areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to right sensory cortex: This is incorrect because sensory input from the right limb is processed in the left sensory cortex, not the right. Therefore, changes due to cortical plasticity would occur in the left cortex, not the right.

 

Option C. Expansion of right sensory cortex: The concept of cortical expansion does not apply here. In cases of amputation, the cortex area corresponding to the amputated limb doesn't expand but rather is taken over by adjacent cortical areas. Also, any changes would occur in the left cortex, not the right.

 

Option D. Expansion of left sensory cortex: While the left sensory cortex is indeed involved, the term "expansion" is not accurate in this context. It is the overlapping projection of adjacent fibers that occurs, not an expansion of the cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cortical plasticity allows adjacent cortical areas to project into regions that have lost their original sensory input, such as after limb amputation. This often leads to phantom limb pain, where the sensation of the missing limb is still perceived.

questions.text:
First part of PCT has which of the following transport proteins? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Sodium potassium pump
  2. Na- glucose co-transporter
  3. Sodium hydrogen antiport
  4. Na+ Bicarbonate cotransporter
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1,2,3

 

1. Sodium-potassium pump: This transporter is found on the basolateral side of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) cells and is critical for maintaining the sodium gradient that drives other transport processes.

 

2. Na-glucose co-transporter: This is located on the apical membrane of PCT cells and uses the sodium gradient to co-transport glucose from the tubular lumen into the cell.

 

3. Sodium-hydrogen antiport: Also on the apical membrane, this antiporter exchanges sodium from the tubular lumen with hydrogen ions from the cell, playing a key role in sodium reabsorption and pH balance.

 

Other Option

 

4. Na+ Bicarbonate cotransporter: It is present in the distal or late part of PCT (Not in the early PCT)- contributes to bicarbonate reabsorption.

The correct combination based on the provided answer is b) 1,2,3, which includes the sodium-potassium pump, the Na-glucose co-transporter, and the sodium-hydrogen antiport, all of which are essential for the function of the PCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proximal convoluted tubule – transport processes –

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in Static Two-point discrimination? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Merkel disk

 

Static two-point discrimination requires a receptor that adapts very slowly to maintain sensation over a prolonged period. Merkel cells are crucial for this function.

 

Merkel cells:

 

  • They are slow-adapting receptors
  • Excellent for 2-point discrimination
  • Have a less receptive field
  • Critical for detecting edges and points
  • Particularly important for tasks like Braille reading

 

The key characteristics that make Merkel cells ideal for static two-point discrimination are:

 

  1. Slow adaptation rate
  2. Ability to detect steady stimuli
  3. Precise localization of sensory input

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Meissner's corpuscles: Incorrect. These are rapidly adapting receptors, making them unsuitable for static discrimination. They are best for fine touch sensations.

 

Option C. Pacinian corpuscles: Incorrect. These are rapidly adapting receptors present at Deep dermis, joint capsule that sense high-frequency vibration and pressure, not static stimuli.

 

Option D. Ruffini ending: Incorrect. While these are slow-adapting mechanoreceptors, they primarily sense stretch and sustained pressure, not precise point discrimination.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Located in the thick muscle layer
Afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch
Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about baroreceptors? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Located in the thick muscle layer

 

Baroreceptors are located in the adventitial layer of the carotid bulb of the internal carotid artery (not in the thick muscle layer); where the walls are typically thinner to allow for the detection of pressure changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stretch receptors: Baroreceptors are indeed stretch receptors; they respond to the stretching of the arterial wall as blood pressure changes.

 

Option C. Afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch: Afferent fibers from the carotid sinus baroreceptors pass through the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) to the brainstem.

 

Option D. Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure: Baroreceptors are sensitive to changes in arterial pressure; they quickly respond to fluctuations in blood pressure by sending signals to the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors are located in the adventitial layer, not in the thick muscle layer, and they are sensitive to changes in arterial pressure, functioning as stretch receptors with afferent fibers passing via the glossopharyngeal nerve.`1

choices.text: It is less than anatomical dead space
It can be measured by spirometry
It is because of inadequate perfusion
It is because of inadequate ventilation

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct about physiological dead space? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is because of inadequate perfusion

 

Physiological dead space refers to the total volume of air that does not participate in gas exchange. It is composed of two components: anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space.

 

Anatomical dead space refers to the volume of air in the conducting airways (from the nose to the terminal bronchioles) that doesn't participate in gas exchange due to the structural anatomy of the respiratory system. The alveolar dead space refers to the volume of air that reaches the alveoli but doesn't participate in gas exchange due to inadequate perfusion of those alveoli.

 

When there is inadequate perfusion (blood flow) to normally ventilated alveoli, a ventilation-perfusion mismatch occurs. This is known as "wasted ventilation" - air reaches the alveoli but since there is insufficient blood flow, the gases cannot be exchanged effectively. This contributes to the physiological dead space.

 

"If there is inadequate perfusion, the alveoli are fine but the problem is in the capillaries. If there is obstruction in the capillaries, fewer molecules of hemoglobin are available to transport oxygen. The remaining oxygen molecules will stay in the alveoli, becoming unexchanged air. This wasted ventilation due to inadequate perfusion adds to physiological dead space."

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is less than anatomical dead space: This is incorrect because physiological dead space equals anatomical dead space in healthy individuals (where alveolar dead space is zero) or exceeds it in pathological conditions (where alveolar dead space is greater than zero). It cannot be less than anatomical dead space because anatomical dead space is determined by the fixed structure of the conducting airways.

 

Option B. It can be measured by spirometry: This is incorrect because spirometry only measures lung volumes and flow rates; it cannot differentiate between exchanged and unexchanged air. Physiological dead space is measured using Bohr's equation, which requires measuring partial pressures of CO2 in exhaled air and arterial blood.

 

Option D. It is because of inadequate ventilation: This is incorrect because inadequate ventilation does not increase dead space. When ventilation is reduced but perfusion is normal, whatever air does reach the alveoli will be completely exchanged due to the preserved perfusion. Inadequate ventilation creates a different type of ventilation-perfusion mismatch called "wasted perfusion" rather than increasing dead space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological dead space is the sum of anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space, with alveolar dead space occurring primarily due to inadequate perfusion of ventilated alveoli, resulting in wasted ventilation.

choices.text: Free iron is toxic for the cells
Iron will be stored in the form of transferrin
Iron is transported via Apoferritin in the blood
Hepcidin enhances iron transport through Ferroportin

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct about iron transport? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Free iron is toxic for the cells

 

Free iron in the body is highly reactive and can catalyze the formation of free radicals, leading to oxidative stress and cellular damage. This is why iron is typically bound to proteins such as transferrin in the blood and ferritin within cells to prevent free iron from causing harm. The body has mechanisms to tightly regulate iron levels to avoid toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iron will be stored in the form of transferrin: This statement is incorrect. Transferrin is a transport protein that carries iron in the bloodstream. Iron is stored in the body as ferritin or hemosiderin, not transferrin.

 

Option C. Iron is transported via Apoferritin in the blood: This is incorrect. Apoferritin binds iron to form ferritin, which is used for storage, not transport. Iron transport in the blood is mainly handled by transferrin.

 

Option D. Hepcidin enhances iron transport through Ferroportin: This is incorrect. Hepcidin actually inhibits iron transport by binding to ferroportin, leading to its degradation. This reduces the amount of iron released into the bloodstream from cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Free iron is toxic to cells due to its ability to generate reactive oxygen species, which can cause significant cellular damage.

choices.text: Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate
Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate→ Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release
Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal
Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens

questions.text: Identify the correct order of End plate potential at the neuromuscular junction: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

 

Explanation:

 

At the neuromuscular junction (NMJ), the sequence of events leading to muscle contraction begins with the binding of acetylcholine (Ach) to its receptors on the motor end plate. This binding opens ligand-gated Na⁺ channels, allowing an influx of sodium ions, which depolarizes the muscle membrane and generates an action potential. The action potential travels along the motor neuron to the axon terminal, where it triggers the opening of voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels. The entry of calcium ions into the axon terminal facilitates the exocytosis of Ach into the synaptic cleft, which then binds to receptors on the muscle fiber to propagate the signal for muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release:
This sequence incorrectly initiates with the opening of ligand-gated Na⁺ channels before Ach is released. In reality, Ach must first be released to bind to these channels and cause their opening. 

 

Option C. Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal:
Ach release is a result of Ca²⁺ entry, not the initial step. This option reverses the correct order of events.

 

Option D. Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens:
This sequence incorrectly places the action potential at the motor end plate before Ach release. The action potential at the motor end plate is a result of Ach binding, not the precursor to Ca²⁺ entry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence at the neuromuscular junction is:

 

Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

questions.text: The graph below shows oxygen dissociation curves. What does the curve marked as red indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

 

The curve 'A' shows a hyperbolic curve that is characteristic of oxygen dissociation in myoglobin.

 

 

The red curve in the graph indicates the oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin. This curve is hyperbolic, which is characteristic of myoglobin's oxygen binding properties.

 

Myoglobin: Myoglobin can bind only one oxygen molecule and does not exhibit cooperative binding like hemoglobin. This results in a hyperbolic oxygen dissociation curve, which means myoglobin has a very high affinity for oxygen and releases it only at low partial pressures of oxygen (PO2). This high affinity allows myoglobin to effectively store oxygen in muscle tissues and release it during periods of low oxygen availability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carboxyhemoglobin: The dissociation curve for carboxyhemoglobin would show a leftward shift and a reduced maximal oxygen carrying capacity due to carbon monoxide binding with high affinity to hemoglobin, but it would not have the hyperbolic shape seen with myoglobin.

 

Option C. Methemoglobin: Methemoglobin has an oxidized form of iron that cannot bind oxygen effectively. The curve would show a decreased oxygen carrying capacity but would not match the hyperbolic shape of the myoglobin curve.

 

Option D. Fetal Hemoglobin (HbF): Fetal hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen compared to adult hemoglobin, resulting in a leftward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve. However, it still exhibits cooperative binding, unlike myoglobin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin is hyperbolic, indicating its high affinity for oxygen and its role in oxygen storage within muscle tissues. This curve differs from the sigmoidal curve of hemoglobin, which exhibits cooperative binding.

questions.text: The image shows changes in membrane potential during an action potential. The region marked between 4 to 5 is due to?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Efflux of K+

 

The action potential curve shows the different phases of an action potential in a neuron. The region marked between 4 and 5 corresponds to repolarization and hyperpolarization.

 

  • Phase 4 to 5 (Repolarization and Hyperpolarization): During this phase, voltage-gated potassium channels remain open, and there is an efflux of K+ ions from the cell, causing the membrane potential to return to the resting level or even become more negative (hyperpolarization).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Influx of Na+: This occurs during the depolarization phase (Phase 0 to 1), not during repolarization.

 

Option B. Efflux of Na+: This does not occur in the action potential phases.

 

Option C. Influx of K+: Potassium ions typically move out of the cell (efflux) during repolarization, not into the cell.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Z line, A band, H zone, I Band
A band, Z line, H zone, M Band
A band, I Band, Z line, H zone
Z line, A band, M Band, H zone

questions.text: Identify the correct labeling (A, B, C, D) in the given image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Z line, A band, H zone, I Band

 

  • A is the Z line: The light line marking the boundary between sarcomeres
  • B (A band): The darker, thicker region representing myosin filaments
  • C (H zone):  The lighter area between the A bands
  • D (I Band): The lighter area between Z lines containing actin filaments

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in an inner segment of the photoreceptor? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Disc 

 

Disc membranes are specifically located in the outer segment of the photoreceptor, not the inner segment. The inner segment contains most cellular organelles, including:

 

  • Mitochondria
  • Endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
  • Golgi apparatus
  • Nucleus

 

The outer segment is characterized by the presence of disc membranes, which are crucial for phototransduction. 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old man weighing 70 kg had a sodium level of 120 mEq, calculate sodium deficit? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 840 mEq

 

Explanation

 

The sodium deficit in the given scenario is 840 mEq.

 

Formula for calculating sodium deficit = 0.6 × body weight x (target plasma sodium concentration - starting plasma sodium concentration).

 

Substituting values as per the question,

 

Sodium deficit = 0.6 x 70 × (140 - 120) = 840 mEq.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Correcting sodium levels must be done cautiously, especially in cases of hyponatremia, to prevent complications like osmotic demyelination syndrome. Rapid changes in serum sodium can be dangerous, and adjustments should generally be made slowly, according to specific clinical guidelines.

questions.text: The graph given below shows the normal FEV1 and FVC curves for a normal lung and a diseased lung. The abnormal graph represents which of the following?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) COPD

 

In the provided spirometry graph, the normal and abnormal curves represent volumes and flow rates during forced expiration.

 

The abnormal graph is indicative of COPD, as it shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, resulting in a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio

 

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by a decrease in FEV1 with a more preserved FVC, leading to a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, which is consistent with the abnormal curve in the graph.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchiectasis: This condition where the walls of airways (bronchi) widen and are thickened from inflammation. It can cause obstructive lung changes, but the FEV1/FVC ratio is often normal or less dramatically reduced than in COPD. The spirometry curve will not show the same pattern as shown in graph.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This is a restrictive lung disease, typically showing a reduction in both FEV1 and FVC but with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, unlike the pattern shown for the diseased lung in the graph.

 

Option C. Pulmonary fibrosis: As a restrictive disease, pulmonary fibrosis would typically show a decrease in lung volumes (including FVC) with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, which differs from the obstructive pattern shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spirometry pattern for COPD shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, leading to a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. This is indicative of obstructive lung disease.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of ventricular action potential in the correct order: (INICET Nov 2022)

 

  1. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels
  2. Repolarizing K+ currents
  3. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
  4. Transient outward flow of potassium
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C, D, A, B

 

The ventricular action potential is characterized by a sequence of changes in membrane potential and ionic currents. The correct sequence is as follows:

 

  1. C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels: This is the initial depolarization phase (Phase 0). When the membrane potential reaches the threshold, voltage-gated sodium channels open, leading to a rapid influx of Na+ ions and a sharp rise in membrane potential.
  2. D. Transient outward flow of potassium: This corresponds to Phase 1. Shortly after the peak of the action potential, transient outward K+ channels open, causing a brief efflux of K+ ions which results in a slight repolarization.
  3. A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels: This is Phase 2, the plateau phase. Voltage-gated L-type calcium channels open, allowing Ca2+ to enter the cell. The influx of Ca2+ is balanced by the efflux of K+ through delayed rectifier K+ channels, maintaining a plateau in the membrane potential.
  4. B. Repolarizing K+ currents: This is Phase 3. The Ca2+ channels close, but the delayed rectifier K+ channels remain open, leading to a net efflux of K+ and returning the membrane potential to its resting value.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for ventricular action potential is as follows:

 

C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels

D. Transient outward flow of potassium

A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels

B. Repolarizing K+ currents

choices.text: Subthalamic nuclei
Globus pallidus

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffered from a stroke 2 days ago. He now presents with involuntary, violent, and flinging movements of the limbs on one side. What is the likely site of lesion in this patient?   (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subthalamic nuclei

 

Explanation

 

Most probable diagnosis as per the clinical history is hemiballismus which is caused by a lesion in subthalamic nuclei.

 

Hemiballismus is a disorder characterized by violent involuntary abnormal movements on one side of the body involving mostly the arm. While walking, the arm swings widely. These movements are called the flinging movements. These movements are due to the release phenomenon because of the absence of inhibitory influence on movements. Hemiballismus occurs due to degeneration of subthalamic nucleus of Luys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Globus pallidus: Incorrect for hemiballismus. Lesions here typically result in different forms of dyskinesia, such as parkinsonism or dystonia, but not hemiballismus.

 

Option C. Putamen: Also incorrect for this symptom. While putamen lesions are involved in many movement disorders, like Huntington's disease and some forms of Parkinson's disease, they do not typically cause hemiballismus.

 

Option D. Caudate nucleus: Incorrect. Lesions in the caudate nucleus are more often associated with Huntington's disease, which leads to chorea—rapid, jerky movements—not the large-amplitude flinging movements seen in hemiballismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with unilateral flinging, violent limb movements following a stroke, the subthalamic nuclei should be considered as the primary site of lesion. This knowledge is crucial for accurate diagnosis and guiding treatment decisions, such as the use of neuroleptics or other interventions to control these disruptive movements.

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
 

Explanation

 

'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contraction of right atrium: This is incorrect for the 'C' wave. The contraction of the right atrium produces the 'A' wave in the JVP, not the 'C' wave. The 'A' wave occurs due to atrial contraction pushing blood against a closed tricuspid valve at the end of diastole.

 

Option C. Passive filling of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive filling of the right atrium contributes to the 'V' wave, which occurs when the right atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole and the tricuspid valve is closed.

 

Option D. Passive emptying of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive emptying of the right atrium is associated with the 'Y' descent, which happens when the tricuspid valve opens in early diastole and blood flows from the right atrium into the right ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Fig: Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x1, y= Negative waves

questions.text: In the below question mechanical receptors are given with their functions. Choose the correctly matched pair.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle - Fast Vibration

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized nerve endings located deep within the skin and other tissues. They are highly sensitive to high-frequency vibrations, making them particularly adept at detecting fast vibrations. These receptors are crucial for perceiving textures and fine details through vibration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ruffini - Fine touch: This is incorrect because Ruffini endings are mechanoreceptors that detect skin stretch, not fine touch. They are deeper in the skin and contribute to the sensation of skin deformation, which is associated with stretch rather than fine touch.

 

Option C. Meissner - Stretch: This is incorrect because Meissner's corpuscles are responsible for detecting light touch, not stretch. They are located near the surface of the skin and are sensitive to changes in texture and slow vibrations.

 

Option D. Merkel - Slow vibration: This is incorrect because Merkel cells are associated with fine touch and two-point discrimination, not slow vibrations. They are particularly sensitive to edges, points, and textures, which aids in tasks like reading Braille.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are responsible for detecting fast vibrations, and Ruffini endings detect skin stretch.

questions.text: A woman suffered from sunburn after enjoying a vacation on a beach. Now while taking a shower lukewarm water (40 degree celsiuis) touches her back causing her to feel pain. What type of receptors are activated by lukewarm water and what causes her to feel pain? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Innocuous thermal receptor - allodynia

 

After a sunburn, the skin becomes sensitive. When the patient takes a bath with 40-degree Celsius water, which is lukewarm and not hot, the warm sensation should not normally cause pain. This temperature is considered a non-painful, or innocuous, thermal stimulus. In this scenario, the innocuous thermal receptors, which usually respond to non-painful stimuli, are activated. However, due to the skin's heightened sensitivity after sunburn, this harmless stimulus results in a painful sensation. This phenomenon, where a normally non-painful stimulus causes pain, is known as allodynia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Noxious thermal receptor - hyperalgesia: This would occur if a painful stimulus led to an exaggerated pain response. However, in this case, the stimulus (40-degree water) is not painful and hence does not activate noxious receptors.

 

Option C. Noxious thermal receptor - allodynia: Allodynia refers to pain resulting from a non-painful stimulus, but noxious receptors respond to painful stimuli. Therefore, this option is incorrect because it misidentifies the type of receptor involved.

 

Option D. Innocuous thermal receptor - hyperalgesia: Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated pain response to a painful stimulus. Since 40-degree water is not a painful stimulus, hyperalgesia is not applicable here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allodynia is a condition where a normally non-painful stimulus, such as lukewarm water, causes pain. This occurs due to the activation of innocuous thermal receptors in the setting of heightened skin sensitivity, such as after a sunburn.

choices.text: Na- Ca transporter

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. SGLT1

 

Explanation

 

ORS contains Na+ and glucose which facilitates glucose absorption through SGLT 1 (Sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter - 1).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT2: Incorrect. SGLT2 is another sodium-glucose linked transporter but is primarily found in the kidneys where it reabsorbs glucose from the filtrate back into the bloodstream. It is not involved in intestinal glucose absorption and thus not relevant to ORS function.

 

Option C. GLUT4: Incorrect. GLUT4 is an insulin-regulated glucose transporter found mainly in adipose tissues and muscle cells. It is not involved in the intestinal absorption of glucose and plays no role in ORS therapy.

 

Option D. Na-Ca transporter: Incorrect. The sodium-calcium exchanger (often referred to as NCX) is primarily involved in the transport of calcium and sodium ions across the cell membrane in many tissues, including cardiac muscle. It does not participate in glucose absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Segment la is due to residual urine
Segment II is due to Laplace law
Micturition fails to happen in segment II
The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the given cystometrogram? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Segment II is due to Laplace Law

 

Explanation:

 

The true statement regarding the given cystometrogram is that segment lb is due to Laplace law.

 

The law of Laplace correlates volume and wall tension, is applicable to urine storage.

 

According to Law of Laplace, the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R.

 

As the bladder gets filled, the radius increases along with the tension, hence there is a slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full, which explains the flatness of the graph in segment II

 

The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL. A marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of 400ml.

 

Cystometrogram is a plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

 

 

  1. Initial Filling Phase (or Low-Pressure Phase): This phase represents the storage phase of bladder function.
  2. Rapid Filling Phase (or High-Pressure Phase): In this phase, the intravesical pressure increases more rapidly as the bladder volume reaches a certain threshold. The detrusor muscle, which contracts to initiate bladder emptying, starts to generate increased pressure as the bladder approaches its capacity. This phase represents the transition from storage to voiding phase.
  3. Voiding Phase (or Micturition Phase): In the voiding phase, the intravesical pressure rises to its highest level as the detrusor muscle contracts forcefully to empty the bladder. The pressure exceeds the urethral resistance, resulting in urine expulsion. This phase is associated with the sensation of needing to urinate and the act of micturition (urination).
